thread.title: Plymouth's lifelong Liverpool fan Graham Carey out to put one over boyhood idols — and his own family
thread.title_full: Plymouth's lifelong Liverpool fan Graham Carey out to put one over boyhood idols — and his own family

author: Nick Parkinson
title: Plymouth's lifelong Liverpool fan Graham Carey out to put one over boyhood idols — and his own family
text:
Sport Plymouth's lifelong Liverpool fan Graham Carey out to put one over boyhood idols — and his own family Midfielder who has always wanted to score at Anfield's Kop End gets his chance in Sunday's FA Cup tie Share Carey has "17 or 18" relatives coming over from Ireland to watch him at Anfield (Photo: Getty Images / PA) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Graham Carey grew up dreaming of scoring in front of the Kop and aims to make it a reality on Sunday – by doing it against Liverpool . 
The lifelong Reds fan will try to pull off one of the biggest FA Cup upsets in recent years with League Two promotion hopefuls Plymouth. 
Carey’s family are all Liverpool fans and are coming over from Dublin for the third-round tie at Anfield, after he sent Argyle through with an extra-time winner at Newport last month. 
The Irishman’s family might have divided loyalties, but the former Celtic and Ross County midfielder insists Argyle can leave Jurgen Klopp’s Premier League title contenders humiliated. 
He said: “I think I’ve got 17 or 18 coming across for it. Carey and boss Derek Adams aim to overcome the 68 places between the two clubs (Photo: Getty) 
"The phone has been going mad for tickets and it will be great to see my family, as not many of them get to come over for games. 
“They might be coming over just because it’s Liverpool, though, as my whole family are ­Liverpool fans. I looked up to Michael Owen and Stevie Gerrard and I used to dream of scoring at Anfield. Hopefully, it’ll be on Sunday – you never know. 
“No one will give us a chance, but, if we stick to our game plan, you never know what can happen in the FA Cup. 
"You have seen it down the years… it can happen.” 
Carey, 27, expects Argyle to be ball-chasing for much of the game – but still reckons they can pull off an unlikely win. 
He said: “It will be a great challenge for us and it will be a day that we can test ourselves against one of the best two teams in the country.
